title: 110_s1891
content: IMMUNITY FOR REPORTS OF SUSPECTED TERRORIST ACTIVITY OR SUSPICIOUS BEHAVIOR AND RESPONSE. Immunity is granted to individuals who report suspected terrorist activity or suspicious behavior in good faith and based on reasonable suspicion. They are protected from civil liability under any law for making such reports, unless the report is knowingly false or made recklessly. Authorized officials who respond to covered activity with reasonable and good faith actions also have qualified immunity from civil liability. Authorized officials who respond to reported activity in good faith are granted qualified immunity from civil liability under applicable law. This immunity also applies to officials who are not entitled to assert qualified immunity but take reasonable action in response to the reported activity. Nothing in this subsection affects an official's ability to assert any other available defense, privilege, or immunity. In this section, authorized officials are granted qualified immunity from civil liability for their actions in response to reported activity. They are entitled to recover reasonable costs and attorney fees if found immune. The term "authorized official" includes employees or agents of transportation systems, Department of Homeland Security, or other entities responsible for security. The term "covered activity" refers to any suspicious transaction or occurrence involving passenger transportation systems indicating a potential violation of law related to threats to passenger safety or security. This includes actions directed against passengers or the transportation system. The term "covered activity" refers to suspicious transactions or occurrences involving passenger transportation systems indicating potential violations of law related to threats to passenger safety or security, including acts of terrorism. Passenger transportation includes public transportation, over-the-road bus transportation, school bus transportation, intercity passenger rail transportation, and passenger vessel transportation. The term "covered activity" pertains to suspicious transactions in passenger transportation systems indicating potential law violations related to passenger safety or security, including terrorism. Passenger transportation includes public transportation, bus transportation, rail transportation, and vessel transportation. Passenger transportation system refers to entities providing passenger transportation using vehicles. The term "vehicle" is defined in the law. The term "covered activity" refers to suspicious transactions in passenger transportation systems indicating potential law violations related to passenger safety or security, including terrorism. This section of the law shall take effect immediately upon enactment and apply to all activities and claims occurring on or after such date.
